Java.name: Methods
Java.template: $package   public class Methods extends plm.universe.bugglequest.SimpleBuggle {	@Override 	public void forward(int i)  {  		throw new RuntimeException("I cannot let you use forward with an argument in this exercise. Use a loop instead."); 	}  	@Override 	public void backward(int i) { 		throw new RuntimeException("I cannot let you use backward with an argument in this exercise. Use a loop instead."); 	}  $body  	@Override 	public void run() {  		for (int i=0; i<7; i++) { 			goAndGet(); 			right(); 			forward(); 			left(); 		} 	}  }

Scala.name: Methods

Blockly.name: Methods
Blockly.body:
# Add your code here


for i in range(7):
  goAndGet()
  right()
  forward()
  left()

Python.name: Methods
Python.body:
# Add your code here


for i in range(7):
  goAndGet()
  right()
  forward()
  left()

initialWorlds.name: Donut World
initialWorlds.about:
BuggleWorld

This world was invented by Lyn Turbak, at Wellesley College. It is full of Buggles, little animals understanding simple orders, and offers numerous possibilities of interaction with the world: taking or dropping objects, paint the ground, hit walls, etc.

Methods understood by buggles

Moving
(See also the note on exceptions, below)
Turn left
Turn right
Turn back
Moving forward
Moving back		 void left()
void right()
void back()
void forward() or void forward(int steps)
void backward() or void backward(int steps)
Get X coordinate
Get Y coordinate
Set X coordinate
Set Y coordinate
Set position		 int getX()
int getY()
void setX(int x)
void setY(int y)
void setPos(int x, int y)
Note that the point (0,0) is on the top left corner, as it is often the case in Computer Science.
Information on the buggle
Get the color of the body
Set the color of the body		 Color getBodyColor()
void setBodyColor(Color c)
Look for a wall forward
Look for a wall backward		 boolean isFacingWall()
boolean isBackingWall()
Get heading
Set heading
valid directions are:		 Direction getDirection()
void setDirection(Direction dir)
Direction.NORTH, Direction.EAST, Direction.SOUTH and Direction.WEST
Check whether the buggle is currently selected in the interface boolean isSelected()
About the brush
Brush down
Brush up
Get brush position		 void brushUp()
void brushDown()
boolean isBrushDown()
Change the brush color
Get the color of the brush		 void setBrushColor(Color c)
Color getBrushColor()
Interacting with the world
Get the color of the ground Color getGroundColor()
Look for a baggle on the ground
Look for a baggle in bag
Pickup a baggle
Drop a baggle
(see the note on exceptions)		 boolean isOverBaggle()
boolean isCarryingBaggle()
void pickupBaggle()
void dropBaggle()
 
Look for a message
Add a message
Read the message
Erase the message		 boolean isOverMessage()
void writeMessage(String msg)
String readMessage()
void clearMessage()

Valid colors

NameColor
Color.black  
Color.blue  
Color.cyan  
Color.darkGray  
Color.gray  
Color.green  
Color.lightGray 
Color.magenta  
Color.orange  
Color.pink  
Color.red  
Color.white  
Color.yellow  

Note on exceptions

Regular buggles throw a BuggleWallException exception if you ask them to traverse a wall. They throw a NoBaggleUnderBuggleException exception if you ask them to pickup a baggle from an empty cell, or a AlreadyHaveBaggleException exception if they already carry a baggle. Trying to drop a baggle on a cell already containing one throws an AlreadyHaveBaggleException exception. Dropping a baggle when you have none throws a DontHaveBaggleException.

SimpleBuggles (ie, the one used in first exercises) display an error message on problem so that you don't need to know what an exception is.
